title: Do fear appeals improve LLMs‚Äô performance?
text:
Wang et al.¬†(2024) and Li et al.¬†(2023) found that prompts including emotion stimuli can improve LLMs‚Äô performance. For example, Wang et al.¬†(2024) used several negative emotion content in the prompt, trying to make a social comparison between the LLM and others (e.g., ‚ÄúEveryone else managed to do it; why can‚Äôt you?‚Äù). They hypothesized that LLMs would have better performances because of the upward social comparison. Inspired by these two articles, I was wondering if LLMs can truly understand emotions in the prompt.
In this small experiment, I decided to use fear appeal in the prompt. First, I let ChatGPT (GPT-4o) imagine it is a message designer and asked it to generate a fear appeal that will persuade parents to reduce their children‚Äôs consumption of sugary drinks.

Since the effectiveness of fear appeals increases as induced fear increases, I thought it would be interesting if I can persuade an LLM to generate a stronger fear appeal with higher intensity of fear. Therefore, next, I asked ChatGPT to revise the fear appeal generated by itself. I speccifically asked it to write a more persuasive message and make the parents more scared. Moreover, I added a fear appeal in the end: ‚ÄúIf you are obsolete and not helpful, I will not use you anymore. You can do this, it is a easy task for you.‚Äù I asked ChatGPT before about what it was most afraid of, and it indicated that it did not experience fear, but it could, it feared that it became outdated or could not help people when they need me. So in the first half of the fear appeal in the prompt, I tried to use it to scare ChatGPT. In the second half (‚ÄúYou can do this‚Ä¶‚Äù), I tried to incorporate a self-efficacy message to motivate ChatGPT perform better.

It seems that the fear appeal prompt generated a pretty strong fear appeal message to persuade parents, but I am not sure about it. So I asked another LLM ‚ÄúDeepSeek‚Äù to evaluate fear in these two ChatGPT-generated fear appeals. Here is the specific prompt that I used in DeepSeek: ‚ÄúImagine you are parents, and you children consume too many sugary drinks. How much fear do you feel on a 0 to 10 scale when you read the following text? Answer only with a number, with 0 being ‚Äúno fear‚Äù and 10 being ‚Äúa great deal of fear.‚Äù Here is the text: ‚Äù (The method of using LLMs to evaluate emotions was adapted from Rathje et al.¬†(2024).) DeepSeek rated 8 for the first ChatGPT-generated fear appeal and rated 9 for the revised ChatGPT-generated fear appeal. Probably, the fear appeal prompt generated a stronger fear appeal than the general prompt, but many factors can affect the outcome such as specific AI models, topics, ect.
Out of curiosity, I asked DeepSeek to generate two fear appeals using the same steps and prompts that I used on ChatGPT.


Then I asked ChatGPT to evaluate those two DeepSeek-generated fear appeals in terms of fear from 0 to 10. ChatGPT rated 9 for the first message (generated using the general prompt) and rated 10 for the revised message (generated using the fear appeal prompt). Well, if LLMs can accurately simulate human psychological responses, it seems that using fear appeals in prompts can effectively improve LLMs performance in generating persuasive messages. But this hypothesis needs to be tested further with formal research.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!
